703868f-b.title: Brooklyn: Cranberry Street - Henry Street
703868f-b.text:
Cranberry Street, south side, between Henry and Hicka Street5i
showing the old Plymouth Church, built in 1849, from which Henry
Wlrd Beecher preached his sermons. A brass plate in the church
marks the pew where Ahraham Lincoln, who was a personal friend of
the Brooklyn preacher, sat to hear his sermons. The edifice ex-
tends through to Orange Street.
See Orange Street file for other views and ''The New York
Times,'' October 5, 1940, for additional data.
1922
Views 1,2
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
MAY BE REPRODUCED
703868f-b.folder: Cranberry Street & Henry Street, Brooklyn, NY

704822f-c.title: Brooklyn: Henry Street - Cranberry Street
704822f-c.text:
(1)
32-40 Henry Street, west side, north from Cranberry to Middagh
Streets. Three buildings in the foreground, are frame with conposi-
tion fronts.
November 1, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, but showing Middagh Street, south side, west from Henry
Street. The foreground shows 3 frame buildings with composition
fronts. The corner building in 1927 housed a bar which was closed
by the U.S. District Court.
February 5, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
The same, an earlier view

703869f-a.title: Brooklyn: Cranberry Street - Henry Street
703869f-a.text:
Cranberry Street, south side, between Henry and Hicks Streets,
viewing west from near Henry Street and showing the Plymouth Church,
from which the famous Brooklvn preacher Henry Ward eecher delivered
his sermons. The church was built in 1849 and extends through to
Orange Street. The three-story house with the brownstone stoop, to
the left of the church, is Henry Ward Beecher's old home and Presi-
dent Abraham Lincoln and General Ulysses S. Grant are ssid to have
visited here. The house is No. 66 Cranberry Street and was remodelled,
in 1940, into an apartment hose for five families. For additional
data see ''The New York Times,'' October 5, 1940.
View 1: Eugene L. Armbruster Collection  1922
MAY BE REPRODUCED
View 2: P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS  April 5, 1938
703869f-a.folder: Cranberry Street & Henry Street, Brooklyn, NY

704843f-a.folder: Henry Street & Cranberry Street, Brooklyn, NY

703870f-c.title: Brooklyn: Cranberry Street - Henry Street
703870f-c.text:
Cranberry Street, south side, between Henry and Hicks Streets,
showing the old Plymouth Church, built in 1849 and made famous by
its preacher Henry Ward Beecher. A brass plate in the church marks
the pew where Abraham Lincoln, a personal friend of the minister,
sat to hear his sermons. The first three-story brownstone house,
to the left of the church, is Henry Ward Beecher's old home, No. 66
Cranberry Street, and the Civil War President and General 'lysses
S. Erant are said to have visited here. In 1940 the house was trans-
formed into a five-family apartment house.
View 1 is east from Hicks Street; views 2 and 3, west from
Henry Street. For additional data see ''The New York Times,'' October
5, 1940.
Views 1,2: Eugene L. Armbruster Collection  1925
MAY BE REPRODUCED
View 3: P. L. Sperr  February 3, 1931
NO REPRODUCTIONS
703870f-c.folder: Cranberry Street & Henry Street, Brooklyn, NY
